metadata.author: Microsoft
metadata.comments: Solution template for Amazon Web Services NetworkFirewall

metadata.description: Not used, but needed to pass arm-ttk test `Location-Should-Not-Be-Hardcoded`.  We instead use the `workspace-location` which is derived from the LA workspace
[concat('Region to deploy solution resources -- separate from location selection',parameters('location'))]
Workspace name for Log Analytics where Microsoft Sentinel is setup
resource group name where Microsoft Sentinel is setup
subscription id where Microsoft Sentinel is setup

properties.displayName: Amazon Web Services NetworkFirewall (via Codeless Connector Platform) (Preview)

connectorUiConfig.title: Amazon Web Services NetworkFirewall (via Codeless Connector Platform) (Preview)
connectorUiConfig.descriptionMarkdown: This data connector allows you to ingest AWS Network Firewall logs into Microsoft Sentinel for advanced threat detection and security monitoring. By leveraging Amazon S3 and Amazon SQS, the connector forwards network traffic logs, intrusion detection alerts, and firewall events to Microsoft Sentinel, enabling real-time analysis and correlation with other security data

dataTypes.name: AWSNetworkFirewall_AlertLog_CL
dataTypes.lastDataReceivedQuery:
AWSNetworkFirewall_AlertLog_CL
 | summarize Time = max(TimeGenerated)
 | where isnotempty(Time)

dataTypes.name: AWSNetworkFirewall_TlsLog_CL
dataTypes.lastDataReceivedQuery:
AWSNetworkFirewall_TlsLog_CL
 | summarize Time = max(TimeGenerated)
 | where isnotempty(Time)

resourceProvider.permissionsDisplayText: Read and Write permissions are required.

parameters.content:
#### 1. AWS CloudFormation Deployment 
 To configure access on AWS, two templates need to be executed in AWS  
 You can find the OIDC Web Identity Provider, AWS Network Firewall Configuration Templates [Here](https://github.com/v-sreddyt/AWS_Networkfirewall/tree/main/CloudFormationTemplates) 
 You can find the detailed steps for deploying the templates [Here](https://github.com/v-sreddyt/AWS_Networkfirewall/blob/main/readme.md)

#### 2. Connect new collectors 
 To enable AWS S3 for Microsoft Sentinel, click the Add new collector button, fill the required information in the context pane and click on Connect.

dataFlows.transformKql: source | extend TimeGenerated = now()  | extend FirewallName = firewall_name, EventTimestamp = event_timestamp, AvailabilityZone = availability_zone, TCPFlags = tostring(event.tcp.tcp_flags), Syn = tobool(event.tcp.syn), Fin = tobool(event.tcp.fin), Psh = tobool(event.tcp.psh), Ack = tobool(event.tcp.ack), Ecn= tobool(event.tcp.ecn), Rst = tobool(event.tcp.rst),AppProto = tostring(event.app_proto), SrcIp = tostring(event.src_ip), SrcPort = tostring(event.src_port), NetFlowPkts = tostring(event.netflow.pkts), NetFlowBytes = tostring(event.netflow.bytes), NetFlowStart = todatetime(event.netflow.start), NetFlowEnd = todatetime(event.netflow.end), NetFlowAge = tostring(event.netflow.age), NetFlowMinttl = tostring(event.netflow.min_ttl), NetFlowMaxttl = tostring(event.netflow.max_ttl), EventType = tostring(event.event_type) | where EventType == "netflow" |extend FlowId = tostring(event.flow_id), DestIp = tostring(event.dest_ip), DestPort = tostring(event.dest_port), Proto = tostring(event.proto)  | project-away event, availability_zone, firewall_name

source | extend TimeGenerated = now(), FirewallName = firewall_name, AvailabilityZone = availability_zone, EventTimestamp = event_timestamp, TxId = tostring(event.tx_id), AppProto = tostring(event.app_proto), SrcIp = tostring(event.src_ip), SrcPort = tostring(event.src_port), EventType = tostring(event.event_type) | where EventType == "alert" | extend Severity = tostring(event.alert.severity), SignatureId = tostring(event.alert.signature_id), Rev = tostring(event.alert.rev), Signature = tostring(event.alert.signature), AlertAction = tostring(event.alert.action), Category = tostring(event.alert.category), FlowId = tostring(event.flow_id), DestIp = tostring(event.dest_ip), DestPort = tostring(event.dest_port), Proto = tostring(event.proto), VerdictAction = tostring(event.verdict.action), Sni = tostring(event.tls.sni), Version = tostring(event.tls.version), PktSrc = tostring(event.pkt_src), Direction = tostring(event.direction) | project-away event

source | extend TimeGenerated = now(), FirewallName = firewall_name, AvailabilityZone = availability_zone, EventTimestamp = event_timestamp, SrcIp = tostring(event.src_ip), SrcPort = tostring(event.src_port), DestIp = tostring(event.dest_ip), DestPort = tostring(event.dest_port), Sni = tostring(event.sni), LeafCertificateFingerprint = tostring(event.leaf_cert_fpr), Status = tostring(event.status), Action = tostring(event.action), ErrorMessage = tostring(event.tls_error.error_message) | project-away event

columns.name: TimeGenerated
columns.description: The timestamp when the log entry was created in AWS Network Firewall.

columns.name: FirewallName
columns.description: The name of the AWS Network Firewall instance generating the log.

columns.name: AvailabilityZone
columns.description: The AWS Availability Zone where the firewall instance is located.

columns.name: TxId
columns.description: The transaction ID associated with the specific network flow.

columns.name: EventTimestamp
columns.description: The epoch timestamp of when the event occurred.

columns.name: AppProto
columns.description: The application layer protocol detected.

columns.name: SrcIp
columns.description: The source port from which the packet originated.

columns.name: SrcPort
columns.description: The source port from which the packet originated.

columns.name: EventType
columns.description: The type of event recorded (e.g., alert, flow, drop, pass).

columns.name: Severity
columns.description: The severity level of the event, typically based on Suricata rule classifications.

columns.name: SignatureId
columns.description: The unique identifier of the Suricata rule that matched the event.

columns.name: Rev
columns.description: The revision number of the matched Suricata rule.

columns.name: Signature
columns.description: The name or description of the Suricata rule that triggered the alert.

columns.name: AlertAction
columns.description: The action taken when an alert was triggered (e.g., allowed, dropped, rejected).

columns.name: Category
columns.description: The category of the detected threat or network activity.

columns.name: FlowId
columns.description: A unique identifier for the network flow related to this event.

columns.name: DestIp
columns.description: The destination IP address of the packet.

columns.name: Proto
columns.description: The protocol used (e.g., TCP, UDP, ICMP).

columns.name: VerdictAction
columns.description: The final decision made by the firewall (e.g., pass, drop, alert).

columns.name: Sni
columns.description: The Server Name Indication (SNI) from TLS traffic.

columns.name: Version
columns.description: The version of the log schema or Suricata rule format used.

columns.name: DestPort
columns.description: The destination port to which the packet was sent.

columns.name: PktSrc
columns.description: The source of the packet (e.g., internal, external, firewall rule).

columns.name: Direction
columns.description: The direction of the traffic (e.g., inbound, outbound).

columns.name: Timestamp
columns.description: The exact timestamp when the event was captured.

columns.name: TimeGenerated
columns.description: The timestamp when the log entry was created in AWS Network Firewall.

columns.name: FirewallName
columns.description: The name of the AWS Network Firewall instance generating the log.

columns.name: AvailabilityZone
columns.description: The AWS Availability Zone where the firewall instance is located.

columns.name: EventTimestamp
columns.description: The epoch timestamp of when the event occurred.

columns.name: TCPFlags
columns.description: The TCP flags observed in the packet

columns.name: Syn
columns.description: Indicates whether the SYN flag is set in the TCP packet (true/false).

columns.name: Fin
columns.description: Indicates whether the FIN flag is set in the TCP packet, signaling the sender wants to gracefully close the connection (true/false).

columns.name: Psh
columns.description: Indicates whether the PSH flag is set in the TCP packet, requesting that the data be pushed to the receiving application immediately (true/false).

columns.name: Ack
columns.description: Indicates whether the ACK flag is set in the TCP packet, acknowledging receipt of data or connection requests (true/false).

columns.name: Rst
columns.description: Indicates whether the RST flag is set in the TCP packet, which resets the connection and abruptly terminates it (true/false).

columns.name: Ecn
columns.description: Indicates whether Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN) is set in the IP header, used to signal network congestion without dropping packets (true/false).

columns.name: AppProto
columns.description: The application layer protocol detected (e.g., HTTP, HTTPS, DNS).

columns.name: SrcIp
columns.description: The source IP address of the packet that triggered the event.

columns.name: SrcPort
columns.description: The source port from which the packet originated.

columns.name: NetFlowPkts
columns.description: The number of packets in the network flow.

columns.name: NetFlowBytes
columns.description: The total number of bytes transferred in the network flow.

columns.name: NetFlowStart
columns.description: The timestamp when the network flow started.

columns.name: NetFlowEnd
columns.description: The timestamp when the network flow ended.

columns.name: NetFlowAge
columns.description: The duration of the network flow in seconds.

columns.name: NetFlowMinttl
columns.description: The minimum Time-to-Live (TTL) observed in the network flow.

columns.name: NetFlowMaxttl
columns.description: The maximum Time-to-Live (TTL) observed in the network flow.

columns.name: EventType
columns.description: The type of event recorded (e.g., flow, alert, drop, pass).

columns.name: FlowId
columns.description: A unique identifier for the network flow related to this event.

columns.name: DestIp
columns.description: The destination IP address of the packet.

columns.name: Proto
columns.description: The protocol used (e.g., TCP, UDP, ICMP).

columns.name: DestPort
columns.description: The destination port to which the packet was sent.

columns.name: Timestamp
columns.description: The exact timestamp when the event was captured.

columns.name: TimeGenerated
columns.description: The timestamp when the log entry was created in AWS Network Firewall.

columns.name: FirewallName
columns.description: The name of the AWS Network Firewall instance generating the log.

columns.name: AvailabilityZone
columns.description: The AWS Availability Zone where the firewall instance is located.

columns.name: EventTimestamp
columns.description: The epoch timestamp of when the event occurred.

columns.name: SrcIp
columns.description: The source IP address of the packet that triggered the event.

columns.name: SrcPort
columns.description: The source port from which the packet originated.

columns.name: DestIp
columns.description: The destination IP address of the packet.

columns.name: DestPort
columns.description: The destination port to which the packet was sent.

columns.name: Sni
columns.description: The Server Name Indication (SNI) from TLS traffic.

columns.name: LeafCertificateFingerprint
columns.description: The SHA-256 fingerprint of the leaf certificate observed in the TLS handshake.

columns.name: Status
columns.description: The status of the TLS inspection event (e.g., success, failure).

columns.name: Action
columns.description: The action taken by the firewall (e.g., allowed, dropped, inspected).

columns.name: ErrorMessage
columns.description: Any error message associated with the event, if applicable.

connectorUiConfig.title: Amazon Web Services NetworkFirewall (via Codeless Connector Platform) (Preview)
connectorUiConfig.descriptionMarkdown: This data connector allows you to ingest AWS Network Firewall logs into Microsoft Sentinel for advanced threat detection and security monitoring. By leveraging Amazon S3 and Amazon SQS, the connector forwards network traffic logs, intrusion detection alerts, and firewall events to Microsoft Sentinel, enabling real-time analysis and correlation with other security data

AWSNetworkFirewall_AlertLog_CL
 | summarize Time = max(TimeGenerated)
 | where isnotempty(Time)

AWSNetworkFirewall_TlsLog_CL
 | summarize Time = max(TimeGenerated)
 | where isnotempty(Time)

resourceProvider.permissionsDisplayText: Read and Write permissions are required.

parameters.content:
#### 1. AWS CloudFormation Deployment 
 To configure access on AWS, two templates need to be executed in AWS  
 You can find the OIDC Web Identity Provider, AWS Network Firewall Configuration Templates [Here](https://github.com/v-sreddyt/AWS_Networkfirewall/tree/main/CloudFormationTemplates) 
 You can find the detailed steps for deploying the templates [Here](https://github.com/v-sreddyt/AWS_Networkfirewall/blob/main/readme.md)

#### 2. Connect new collectors 
 To enable AWS S3 for Microsoft Sentinel, click the Add new collector button, fill the required information in the context pane and click on Connect.

properties.displayName: Amazon Web Services NetworkFirewall (via Codeless Connector Platform) (Preview)

connectorDefinitionName.defaultValue: Amazon Web Services NetworkFirewall (via Codeless Connector Platform) (Preview)

properties.descriptionHtml:
Note: Please refer to the following before installing the solution:

Review the solution Release Notes

There may be known issues pertaining to this Solution, please refer to them before installing.

The Amazon Web Services Network Firewall for Microsoft Sentinel allows you to enable Security monitoring of AWS services by allowing ingestion of logs from the AWS S3Bucket, SQS Queue.

NOTE: Microsoft recommends installation of Amazon Web Services NetworkFirewall (via Codeless Connector Platform). This connector is build on the Codeless Connector Platform (CCP), which uses the Log Ingestion API, which replaces ingestion via the deprecated HTTP Data Collector API. CCP-based data connectors also support Data Collection Rules (DCRs) offering transformations and enrichment.

Data Connectors: 1

Learn more about Microsoft Sentinel | Learn more about Solutions
